Award.AwardTitle: Transforming Undergraduate Learning in Digital Systems in Texas (TX DS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is to adapt and implement use of a video game for improved student learning of engineering digital systems concepts at the undergraduate level and for use in motivating pre-college students (grade 8-12) to pursue electrical engineering, computer engineering, or computer science degrees in college. The objectives include (1) Create new student learning materials and strategies by expanding the digital systems video game, PlanetK, to include more advanced levels that address circuit minimization and sequential system design, and to vertically integrate a conceptual or pedagogical approach on digital system design into sequences of courses in electrical and computer engineering (ECE) and computer science (CS) curricula; (2) Enhance the understanding of digital systems by diverse populations through adaptation and implementation of the video game, PlanetK, beyond a single institution through crowdsourcing to the ECE and CS programs at minority-serving institutions; (3) Contribute to the knowledge base on university and precollege student attitudes toward the use of video games as a motivator for pursuing an ECE or CS major, and determine the effect on student performance, especially on students from underrepresented groups; (4) Implement PlanetK in pre-college outreach efforts for middle and high schools; and (5) Synthesize and disseminate findings across the TAMU System engineering programs, and programs across the nation and the world.

The project will advance discovery and understanding of the impact of video games to improve student learning in ECE and CS disciplines, broaden participation by under-represented minorities and benefit society by improving the understanding of digital systems and engineering for those who do not choose engineering careers, but are part of the non-technically degreed US population.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Transforming Undergraduate Learning in Digital Systems in Texas (TX-DS) project builds on findings of two prior NSF projects and a workshop on student learning.  The project assembled a team of experts from three partner institutions at a very high research University - Texas A&M University, a historically black college and universities (HBCU) - Prairie View A&M University, and a hispanic-serving institution (HSI) - Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi, to review and revise both the content of the PlanetK video game and the content mastery test that served as the pre and posttest for the research conducted with PlanetK. PlanetK was continuously enhanced from 2015-2019 based on findings from its use in courses at the three partner institutions and playtesting of novice and advanced students. The video game was tested with a total of 585 students at the three partner institutions. Lastly in 2019, playtesting was conducted in partnership with the Texas A&M University Live Lab to develop a methodology for students to use the game outside of a course framework.

PlanetK provides three different types of instructional aid tools. Two of the tools proved to be very useful while the third tool was not very helpful. PlanetK also provides two different types of help within the game (Text-based and Video-based help), which are under user control, providing just-in-time help and which results show to be equally useful.

Finally the project developed a community of education and engineering researchers who reviewed and revised both the content of the PlanetK video game and a content mastery test, and tested PlanetK at their institutions with diverse student populations.

Five conference papers were presented and one journal paper under review disseminated the findings of the project to advance discovery and understanding of the impact of video games to improve student learning in elctrical and computer engineering disciplines. Also the findings promote innovations in the use of technology tools in the teaching of an engineering curriculum and student learning through the use of video gaming.


Last Modified: 12/30/2019
Modified by: Karen L Butler-Purry
